official-title.#text:
To amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to increase criminal penalties for the sale or
			 trade of prescription drugs knowingly caused to be adulterated or
			 misbranded, to establish recall authority regarding drugs, and for other
			 purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Tim Fagan’s Law
Counterfeit Drug Enforcement Act of 2014

header.#text:
Sale or trade of prescription drugs knowingly caused to be adulterated or misbranded;
			 misrepresentation as approved drugs

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following paragraphs:

act-name.#text: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, if the person knowingly caused the drug to be adulterated or
			 misbranded and sells or trades the drug, or the person purchases or trades
			 for the drug knowing or having reason to know that the drug was knowingly
			 caused to be adulterated or misbranded, the person shall be fined in
			 accordance with title 18, United States Code, or imprisoned for any term
			 of years or for life, or both.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act/s:503/ss:b/p:1/sp:B

quoted-block.@act-name: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act

header.#text: Order To cease distribution of drug; notification of health professionals

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
finds that a drug intended for human use may constitute a threat to the public
			 health, the

shall issue an order requiring the appropriate
			 person (including the manufacturers, importers, distributors, or retailers
			 of the drug)—

text.#text: If the
to immediately cease distribution of the drug; and

to immediately notify health professionals of the order and to instruct such professionals to cease
			 administering, distributing, selling, or prescribing the drug.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
determines that inadequate grounds exist to support the actions
			 required by the order, the
shall vacate the order.

text.#text:
An order under paragraph (1) shall provide the person subject to the order with an opportunity for
			 an informal hearing, to be held not later than 10 days after the date of
			 the issuance of the order, on the actions required by the order and on
			 whether the order should be amended to require a recall of the drug
			 involved. If, after providing an opportunity for such a hearing, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
determines that the order should be amended to include a recall of the
			 drug with respect to which the order was issued, the

shall,
			 except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3), amend the order to require a
			 recall. The

shall specify a timetable in which the drug recall
			 will occur and shall require periodic reports to the

describing
			 the progress of the recall.

text.#text: If, after providing an opportunity for an informal hearing under subsection (a)(2), the
An amended order under paragraph (1)—
shall not require recall of a drug from individuals; and
shall provide for notice to individuals subject to the risks associated with the use of the drug.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may use the assistance of
			 health professionals who administered the drug involved to individuals or
			 prescribed the drug for individuals. If a significant number of such
			 individuals cannot be identified, the

shall notify such
			 individuals pursuant to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act/s:705/ss:b

text.#text: In providing the notice required by paragraph (2)(B), the

shall develop and implement a procedure through which the
			 Chief Counsel in the

is authorized to issue
			 subpoenas regarding investigations under this Act of acts or omissions
